page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: The area in this study is part of the parish of Stenness in Orkney, a parish which gets its name from the standing stones on the point or 'ness'. 56% of the study area is made up of land and the remainder is water. Of the water area most of it is taken up with the Stenness Loch, an arm of the sea and the remainder is the Harray Loch, a freshwater loch itself joined to the Stenness Loch through a narrow opening over which passes the Brig o' Brogar. Where the Stenness Loch joins the sea properly a bridge called the Brig o' Waithe passes over it carrying the main road, the A965 between Kirkwall and Stromness, the two principal towns. The area has been anciently settled as we know from some of the many prehistoric monuments which are found in the locality.
